metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: Petitioner, resident of Delhi, admitted as student in third year B.B.S. course at Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, Indore, run by State of Madhya Bharat, in July 1952.
College rules discriminate in fees: non-residents of Madhya Bharat pay Rs. 1,500 per annum capitation fee in addition to tuition fees payable by all.
Petitioner paid Rs. 3,000 capitation fee for first two years and seeks refund and prohibition for current year.
College originated in 1878 as Indore Medical School by Dr. Beaumont, became King Edward Memorial School in 1910, upgraded to Medical College in 1947-48, affiliated to University of Agra.
In 1940, Committee collected funds from donors promising nomination rights and capitation fee of Rs. 1,300 from nominees.
Maximum 50 students per year: nominees (reserved seats) and self-nominees (merit-based); Madhya Bharat students exempted from capitation fees.
State took over college on 17-3-1951 subject to seat reservations for nominees of states and donors.
Post-takeover rule: No capitation fee for bona fide residents of Madhya Bharat; Rs. 1,300 for nominees, Rs. 1,500 for other non-residents.

Bona fide resident defined as: (a) citizen with original domicile in MP not acquired elsewhere; (b) citizen acquired domicile in MP + 5 years residence; (c) Pakistan migrant before 30-9-1948 intending permanent residence; (d) declaration by MP Govt for adjacent areas.
Rule modified post Rustam Mody case: Exemption only for bona fide residents selected for reserved seats.
Admission by competitive exam; seats allocated: reserved for MP residents, nominees (lower capitation), self-nominees (higher capitation).

legal_issues.text: Whether the rule imposing capitation fee on non-bona fide residents of Madhya Bharat while exempting bona fide residents violates Articles 14 and 15(1) of the Constitution.
Whether the definition of 'bona fide resident' based on domicile equates to discrimination on place of birth under Article 15(1).
Whether classification based on residence/domicile is reasonable under Article 14.
Whether regional domicile (Madhya Bharat domicile) is recognizable under the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule discriminates on place of birth by exempting Madhya Bharat students/non-residents pay capitation fee, violating Article 15(1).
Definition of bona fide resident via original domicile means place of birth; clause (d) irrational, favors foreigners.
Imposition discriminatory under Article 14 as arbitrary classification.

respondent_arguments.text: Exemption based on bona fide residence, not place of birth; residence distinct from birth.
Classification on residence reasonable to benefit state residents, aid education; state contributes to upkeep.
State took over subject to existing conditions; rules administrative, not 'law' under Article 13.
'Domicile' in rule means residence in popular sense, not technical.

court_reasoning.text: Residence and place of birth distinct; Article 15(1) prohibits only birth-based discrimination, not residence/domicile.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Domicile of origin not synonymous with place of birth.

court_reasoning.text: Domicile means permanent home; possible for regions with distinct laws; Constitution allows state laws on personal matters.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regional domicile (MP) conceivable under Concurrent List.

court_reasoning.text: Classification on residence reasonable: aids state education, benefits locals who may serve state.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Geographical classification valid per State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Clause (d) severable; no need to decide its validity.
Dissent: Rule camouflages place of birth discrimination; no regional domicile concept in India; offends Article 15(1) and 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Original domicile means place of birth in Indian context.

holdings.text: Rule not violative of Article 15(1) as based on residence/domicile, not place of birth.
Classification on bona fide residence reasonable and has nexus to object of aiding state education.

precedents_cited.relevance: Domicile of origin not place of birth; multiple domiciles possible.
Domicile of birth not accurate term.
Distinguishes political status (citizenship) from civil status (domicile).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh

precedents_cited.relevance: Rules as executive orders may not be 'law' under Article 13.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under 32 for enforcement of 14 and 15(1); classification tested under 14; citizenship/domicile under 5; directive on education 41, uniform civil code 44.

outcome.summary: Majority dismisses the petition holding the capitation fee rule constitutional, not violating Articles 14 or 15(1); Jagannadhadas J. dissents, would allow petition.

key_quotes.text: "Residence and place of birth are two distinct conceptions with different connotations both in law and in fact."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core distinction upholding rule under Article 15(1).

key_quotes.text: "The classification is thus based on a ground which has a reasonable relation to the subject-matter of the legislation."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The phrase original domicile in Madhya Bharat is meant to convey the place of birth of the applicant in Madhya Bharat."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent's key finding striking down rule.

key_quotes.text: "Domicile meant permanent home, and if that was not understood by itself no illustration could help to make it intelligible."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines domicile citing Whicker v. Hume.
